items.label: Using the BOBA Token Bridge Between L1s
Adding a new ERC20 to Boba

account-abstraction/biconomy.title: Biconomy Integration with Boba
account-abstraction/biconomy.description: In this tutorial, we'll walk through the process of integrating Biconomy with Boba chain to enable gasless transactions.

account-abstraction/bundler-sdk.title: Bundler SDK
account-abstraction/bundler-sdk.description: This section documents the usage of the Bundler SDK, that is a major component of Account Abstraction.

account-abstraction/index.title: Overview
account-abstraction/index.description: In general there are two types of accounts on Ethereum:

account-abstraction/paymasters.title: Account Abstraction Paymasters
account-abstraction/paymasters.description: These custom paymasters, as per compatibiltiy with ERC4337 Account Abstraction design, will allow users to pay gas for txs using 'any' ERC20 token, and without needing any protocol level changes. The Sequencer however, would still only continue to accept the fee token it identifies as per the protocol, the Paymaster pays for the userOp execution, with their deposit on the Entrypoint in denominations of the native token and accepts the alt erc20 token as payment in return.

addresses/index.title: Overview
addresses/index.description: Here you can find all boba-related contract and token addresses. Some contract addresses are featured in other docs, linked here:

addresses/network-bnb.title: Boba BNB Network Contract Addresses
addresses/network-bnb.description: <!-- * \[Boba BNB Testnet L2 (9728) for the BNB Testnet (97)]

basics/add-new-token.title: Adding a new ERC20 to Boba
basics/add-new-token.description: Adding a new ERC20 token to Boba

basics/basic-ops.title: Basic Operations
basics/basic-ops.description: Learn how to use basic features of Boba (e.g. bridges, basic L2 ops) through examples

basics/bridging/boba-token-bridge.title: Using the BOBA Token Bridge Between L1s
basics/bridging/boba-token-bridge.description: Learn more about the BOBA Token Bridge Between L1s

basics/bridging/index.title: Introduction
basics/bridging/index.description: Although Boba Network is an L2 (and therefore fundamentally connected to an L1), it's also a separate blockchain system. App developers commonly need to move data and assets between Boba Network and Ethereum or an alt-L1 like BNB Chain. We call the process of moving data and assets between the two networks "bridging".

basics/bridging/light-bridge.title: Using the Light Bridge
basics/bridging/light-bridge.description: Learn more about the Light Bridge

basics/bridging/standard-bridge.title: Using the Standard Token Bridge
basics/bridging/standard-bridge.description: Learn more about the Standard Token Bridge

basics/json-rpc-api.title: JSON-RPC API
basics/json-rpc-api.description: Boba Network shares the same JSON-RPC API (opens new window) as Ethereum. Some new custom methods have been introduced and some other have been made unsupported for operation.

basics/verify-sc.title: Verifying Contracts
basics/verify-sc.description: Learn how to verify smart contracts on Boba

fees/fee-scheme.title: Fees
fees/fee-scheme.description: Fees on Boba are, for the most part, significantly lower than L1s. The cost of every transaction is the sum of two values:

hc/addsub/README.title: Add-Subtract Example
hc/addsub/README.description: The purpose of our next smart contract example is to explore more in-depth technical detail in a smart contract using Hybrid Compute. That depth includes writing and calling an off-chain handler. This contract can do two things:

hc/addsub/write-contract.title: Write the Smart Contract
hc/addsub/write-contract.description: To start our contract, we need to import the interface to our HybridAccount contract. The address of this HybridAccount is passed to the constructor and is stored as an immutable variable. Next we define other contract variables and helper functions.

hc/addsub/write-handler.title: Write an Off-Chain Handler
hc/addsub/write-handler.description: The first step is to write our off-chain handler. This handler is responsible for receiving requests from the bundler along with their payloads and returning the appropriate responses.

hc/deploy-contract.title: Deploy the Smart Contracts
hc/deploy-contract.description: A deploy-local.py script is provided to deploy and configure the necessary contracts on a local stack, launched from make devnet-up in a Boba/Optimism repository.

hc/index.title: Introduction
hc/index.description: Welcome to the developer documentation for implementing a basic example with our system and API. This guide will walk you through the necessary steps to get started and provide you with the information you need to successfully integrate our system into your project. Additionally, you can view a full example on our Github.

hc/price-fetch.title: Price Fetch Example
hc/price-fetch.description: To dip our toes into Hybird Compute's capabilities, consider the following simple smart contract which fetches the price of different cryptocurrencies. You can view the full example in our repository.

hc/server-setup.title: Set Up a Server
hc/server-setup.description: For any smart contract, with or without an off-chain handler, the next step is to set up a server to run it. In this example, we will create a simple JSON-RPC server using the jsonrpclib library:

index.title: Introduction
index.description: Boba is the first scaling infrastructure that is deployed on multiple blockchains, making it the leading Web3 multichain execution layer with scaling capabilities to facilitate more functionality on EVM-compatible blockchains.

indexers/subgraph.title: Using The Graph
indexers/subgraph.description: The Graph is a decentralized protocol for indexing and querying data from blockchains.

indexers/subquery.title: Subquery Indexer
indexers/subquery.description: SubQuery is a leading blockchain data indexer that provides developers with fast, flexible, universal, open source and decentralised APIs for web3 projects. SubQuery SDK allows developers to get rich indexed data and build intuitive and immersive decentralised applications in a faster and more efficient way. SubQuery supports 100+ ecosystems including Boba, Cosmos, Ethereum, Polygon, Polkadot, Algorand, NEAR, and Avalanche.

node-operators/index.title: Overview
node-operators/index.description: The anchorage is activated on Sepolia Testnet. For other networks, please refer to Replica Node (Legacy).

node-operators/network-upgrades.title: Network Upgrade Overview
node-operators/network-upgrades.description: This section has information on how to upgrade your Mainnet and Testnet nodes for new network upgrades.

node-operators/run-node-docker.title: Running a Node with Docker
node-operators/run-node-docker.description: This tutorial will walk you through the process of using Docker to run an BOBA Sepolia node, OP Mainnet node and OP Sepolia node. You can find all Docker Compose files here.

node-operators/run-node-source.title: Running a Node from Source
node-operators/run-node-source.description: DDocker images make it very simple to run a BOBA node, but you can also create your own node using the source code. You might choose to do this if you need the node to work on a  specific architecture or if you want to look closely at the node's code. This guide will show you how to build and run a node from scratch.

node-operators/snapshot-downloads.title: Node Snapshots
node-operators/snapshot-downloads.description: This page has a list of important snapshots for node operators. Data directories and node snapshots are not required but can significantly simplify the node operation process.

node-operators/software-release.title: Node Software Releases
node-operators/software-release.description: This page provides a list of the necessary versions of node software and instructions on how to keep them updated.
